It varies. Some people have "amusicalia" and music sounds like random sounds to them. Some deaf people dance to rhythms they feel throb through their bodies. Some, like me, swoon helplessly to Dvorak. C&W makes me puke. Once in HS I played Pachabel's Cannon in D to a redneck dude who listened politely for a moment and then asked me when it started. My daughter wasn't particularly interested in classical music until, at age 25 when she heard some Vivaldi on the radio she'd heard a thousand times growing up and never notices. She had to pull over because her tears made it impossible to drive. When she was six she could sing every one of Brittany whazzername's "songs".... One's reactions to music has something to do with maturity. A member of a "first contact" anthropologist team that went to Papua NG  many decades ago tried playing the natives some Beethoven using a wind-up phonograph. The natives laughed hysterically. In other words, it's cultural.  Xtmas muzak in Sept. drives everyone nuts; it's situational/context. It's amazing.
